Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 06:03PM Annaanne wrote: Hi Deb. I'm a stage 3er and so sorry about your active nodes.  I've been following your thread. Here's my ativan experience -- my onc says it stimulates the same part of your brain as alcohol (very pleasant!)  It is addictive, if you care.  If you want to avoid getting physically used to it, don't take it more than 2 or 3 days in a row.  If you do take get used to it and take it every day for a while, then want to quit, just get a pill cutter and reduce very gradually.  You may have a few sleepless nights, but it's not that hard to get off. Take care.  We are all pitching for you and sending our best thoughts. Annaanne

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 04:23PM Annaanne wrote: I can highly, highly recommend Dr. Armando Giuliano and his partners at St. John's hospital in Santa Monica (Joyce Eisenberg Keefer Breast Center.)  He's a surgeon who specializes in bc and trains many young docs now.  That may be too far from Irvine, although for surgery you don't need to go that often.  If your friend has to do chemo, it's more important that the oncologist or rads doc is close.  I think Giuliano and his partners are the absolute best...anywhere.  A good surgeon can also recommend a plastics doc  310 582 7100  Annaanne  PS.  The way to find good docs is to ask everyone you know, especially if you have friends in the medical profession or who have had bc themselves.  You'll start getting the same names over and over.
Posts.Title: How to find good doctors ailenroc mj1016

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 06:28PM Annaanne wrote: Hi Allenroc: Yes, Giuliano did my surgery.  I had a large tumor and he was able to safely do breast conservation.  The cosmetic result is fantastic.  I've had no lymphadema problems (I always think the skill of the surgeon has an effect on that -- maybe I'm wrong) even though I had complete node dissection.  I also had a cold resident who checked on me, but have since seen a new partner for a check up, and she was great.   Yes, it is a hugely busy office and there is the usual arrogance of surgeons.  BUT...I don't care about that.  What I care about is medical judgement and skill and the experience to know what to do at the time of the surgery.  For me, my most important time with the surgeon was when I was unconscious. Also, I go there for all my follow up, despite living in Oregon.  I get results from my mammos within 15 minutes.  I get MRI results the next day.  I always have my scans on the same machines, read by the same radiologists.  When I have mammos, Giuliano also looks at them himself every time.   The nurses there are great.  I feel like I am in really good hands.  I am so grateful I found him. Everybody is different and your friend will know what's important to her.  It's such a personal decision.  Hope this helps.  By the way, I'm 4 1/2 years from dx and doing great. Good luck A  I know how important people skills are at the time of dx, when you are so scared.  But in retrospect, I wouldn't look for that from my surgeon.  Of course, you need to be able to talk to them, but I think personality is more important with an oncologist, who you will see much more often.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 04:12PM Annaanne wrote: Hi again.  Like Sherri, I lost about 5 pounds during chemo, and in fact my onc lectured me about not losing too much weight.  Sure, some women gain, but just as many lose or stay the same.   I took an hour walk with a friend almost every day during chemo -- I recommend that.  I also ate lots of starchy foods, but my body was burning calories like crazy.   Maybe you should interview another onc and consider switching before you start treatment... Annaanne stage 3a, dx 5/05.  Ned

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 07:30PM Annaanne wrote: Hey Elaine: Welcome home and congrats on having your surgery behind you. And thanks for letting me know. Let your family and dog take care of you. Be patient over the next few months, especially if you do more chemo. But then you'll be amazed how your body can recover. I discovered this board right after my surgery -- and it was great to find so many other women who'd had dx similar to mine, had totally recovered and were thriving! All the best Annaanne (all the way across the country -- in Oregon)

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 02:28AM Annaanne wrote: I had the experience of false positives (twice) on routine scans that my onc ordered.  I was the one to finally say, "No more scans without symptoms!"  I know most women want information, but false positives are not only horribly stressful, they can lead to unneeded surgeries like lung or liver biopsies, which can be major operations.  There are definately two sides to this issue. A

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 05:32PM Annaanne wrote: Hi Bobbie: I think you've gotten some good advice here. You've gone through this extraordinarily scary dx, then treatment while raising kids and tending to a sick husband! And you've kept it together until now! You are one strong, amazing woman. But you can't keep it up forever. You must refill and recharge. Can you get help? Housecleaning? Cooking? Child care just so you can flake out? Can you carve out any time/money to do things that will relax and re energize you? (and give you permission to do nothing for a few hours) Massage, acupuncture, therapy, reading in bed, going to movies and plays, etc. Can friends of your husband's help with his needs? Do your friends and relatives know that you need some relief? Are you so competent that no one thinks of offering help? What you're feeling sounds totally appropriate considering your situation. Annanne

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 01:39AM Annaanne wrote: Hi Davebobbie: So glad to hear you're feeling better. It's like raising kids, isn't it -- knowing when to push and when to coddle. There's no formula, just a lot of guesswork...and guts. Annaanne
Posts.Title: Freaked Out SpunkyGirl Annaanne

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 12:39AM Annaanne wrote: To add to this discussion: I had neo chemo in '05, 3 months of A/C, then 3 mos of Taxotere/herceptin.  I did not have a good response (I still had stage 3a disease at surgery.) So,  I consulted a couple of oncs about whether to do more chemo after surgery.  The consensus was (at that time) that there was no research to support the benefit of additional chemo.  I continued with rads and 9 months more of herceptin, but no more chemo.   I've done really well, by the way.  No recurrence.  Highly her pos, hormone neg, very aggressive path. Annaanne
